Comment: Odd move, don't do that.
Odd move, don't do that.
g5 is still possible, but it doesn't go well for black (told by experience).
g5 is still possible, but it doesn't go well for black (told by experience).
g5 is still possible, but it doesn't go well for black (told by experience).
Threatening e4.
Threatening e4.
Not "seeing" it.
? Stupidly leaving e4.
Clearing the way for castling and supporting his lsb. Black here misses a much better move: can you spot it?
? Starting a "standard" plan, without looking carefully to the board. e4 was still possible! (...and necessary, since Nb4 would have been very unconfortable for white!)
Finally stops e4, at the cost of a tempo. He is also freeing the way for his dsb. Prepares Nb4, in a way.
Standard attack, giving up kingside castling perspectives at all.
This "wonderful" Bishop can be easily controlled by white, who just leaves it there.

BxN, NxN would be very fine for me. So black has a wonderful piece... Now. But white can exchange it when he wants, making Nb4 almost useless. Black has Nb5, but in that case I (white) plays NxB, then Nf3-d2, and everything's ok.
What an aggressive move! Nice! Of course it uncovers the kingside.
Eliminating the Nb4 jump, and setting a nasty threat on black. Which one?
After white retakes, black must be aware of a trapped B... did you realize it?
Normally I take it with the pawn, but in this case, this B here is a monster, since no pawn nor N can exchange it, and black's dsb is condemned to g7's defence for some time.

! ...or it should be. Black gives his K a remote fortress instead of the useless fxg4. g5 would have been an option, or e6 - Bd6. But before those plans can be even considered, black should have taken care of white's f3, that traps the "wonderful" bishop.
I ovelooked it! Instead, I started right away the queenside attack. No reason to lose time: dxc4, Bxc4, and d4 is still solid.
Right, and I have to be careful about a possible / future Bb4(+), so I preferred to... (still ignoring f3, which may have came to be a better choice than to take it).
This works because after f6, white can still attack via a Ba6 sac at some point.
? No, wrong direction. Black doesn't have time for counterattack on f2. And still doesn't see the potentially trapped B.
